verses.text: Solomon made an alliance with Pharaoh king of Egypt and took Pharaoh's daughter as his wife. He brought her to the city of David until he finished building his own house, the house of the LORD, and the wall around Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Pharaoh's daughter is noted later as being moved because she was not to dwell in David's house which was holy.

verses.text: But the people were still sacrificing at the high places because a house had not yet been built for the Name of the LORD.
verses.comment: High places refer to local worship sites not centered in Jerusalem; Deuteronomy requires central worship.

verses.text: Solomon loved the LORD, walking in the statutes of David his father; but he also sacrificed and burned incense at the high places.
verses.comment: Even Solomon continued some practices that would later be prohibited.

verses.text: And the king went to Gibeon to sacrifice there, because it was the most important high place. Solomon offered a thousand burnt offerings on that altar.
verses.comment: Gibeon was the site of the tabernacle at this time; see 2 Chron. 1:3.

verses.text: At Gibeon the LORD appeared to Solomon in a dream by night, and God said, "Ask for whatever you want me to give you."
verses.comment: God's invitation to request.

verses.text: Solomon answered, "You have shown great, steadfast love to your servant David my father, because he walked before you in faithfulness, righteousness, and uprightness of heart toward you. And you have kept for him this great kindness and have given him a son to sit on his throne, as it is today."
verses.comment: Steadfast love translates Hebrew 'hesed'; refers to God’s covenant loyalty.

verses.text: "Now, LORD my God, you have made your servant king in place of David my father, though I am only a child; I do not know how to go out or come in."
verses.comment: "Child" here means one inexperienced, not necessarily of young age.

verses.text: "Your servant is among your people whom you have chosen, a great people, too many to be counted or numbered."
verses.comment: God’s promise to Abraham of countless descendants referenced.

verses.text: "Therefore, give your servant an understanding heart to judge your people, to discern between good and evil; for who can judge this great people of yours?"
verses.comment: "Understanding heart" translates Hebrew for discerning, listening heart.

verses.text: The request pleased the Lord, that Solomon had asked for this.
verses.comment: God expresses approval of Solomon’s request.

verses.text: God said to him, "Because you have asked for this, and have not asked for long life, nor riches for yourself, nor the death of your enemies, but have asked for understanding to discern justice,
verses.comment: Solomon’s priorities are contrasted with typical royal requests.

verses.text: "I will do as you have asked. I give you a wise and discerning heart, so that no one like you has been before you nor will ever rise like you afterwards."
verses.comment: "Wise and discerning heart" points to intellectual and moral insight.

verses.text: "And I also give you what you did not ask for—both riches and honor, so that in your lifetime no other king will compare to you."
verses.comment: God adds wealth and honor to Solomon’s wisdom.

verses.text: "And if you walk in my ways, keeping my statutes and my commandments as your father David did, then I will give you long life."
verses.comment: Conditional long life; hinges on obedience.

verses.text: Then Solomon awoke, and realized it had been a dream. He went to Jerusalem, stood before the ark of the covenant of the LORD, offered burnt offerings and peace offerings, and held a feast for all his officials.
verses.comment: Ark was in Jerusalem; tabernacle was at Gibeon at this time.

verses.text: Then two women who were prostitutes came to the king and stood before him.
verses.comment: Their status emphasizes Solomon’s impartiality in judgment.

verses.text: One of the women said, "My lord, this woman and I live in the same house, and I gave birth to a child while she was in the house.
verses.comment: Opening of the famous judicial case.

verses.text: "On the third day after I gave birth, this woman also gave birth. We were alone; no one else was in the house except we two."
verses.comment: No witnesses ensures the need for wise judgment.

verses.text: "During the night, this woman's son died because she lay on him."
verses.comment: Accidental suffocation.

verses.text: "So she got up in the middle of the night and took my son from beside me while your servant slept. She laid him at her breast, and laid her dead son at my breast."
verses.comment: Details of the alleged deception.

verses.text: "When I rose in the morning to nurse my son, I saw that he was dead; but when I looked at him closely, I realized it was not the son I had borne."
verses.comment: Key testimony; the mother recognizes her own child.

verses.text: The other woman said, "No, the living child is mine, and the dead child is yours." But the first one replied, "No, the dead child is yours, and the living child is mine." So they spoke before the king.
verses.comment: The dispute presented before Solomon.

verses.text: Then the king said, "This one says, 'My son is the living one, and your son is the dead one,' and the other says, 'No, your son is the dead one, and my son is the living one.'"
verses.comment: Solomon restates the case.

verses.text: And the king said, "Bring me a sword." So they brought a sword before the king.
verses.comment: Solomon’s bold test.

verses.text: And the king said, "Divide the living child in two, and give half to one and half to the other."
verses.comment: Dramatic, seemingly ruthless proposal.

verses.text: Then the woman whose son was alive spoke to the king, because her heart yearned for her son, and she said, "Please, my lord, give her the living child—do not kill him!" But the other said, "He shall be neither mine nor yours; divide him."
verses.comment: Mother’s compassion reveals her true identity.

verses.text: Then the king answered, "Give the living child to the first woman, and do not kill him; she is his mother."
verses.comment: Solomon’s wisdom displays discernment.

verses.text: And all Israel heard of the judgment the king had rendered. They stood in awe of the king because they saw that the wisdom of God was in him to do justice.
verses.comment: Solomon’s fame for wisdom begins; "the wisdom of God" emphasizes divine source.
